Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description: Alonzo Mourning had 28 points and 11 rebounds, and Jimmy Jackson scored eight of his 19 points in the fourth quarter Wednesday night as the Miami Heat reached the 100-point plateau for the first time this season.
article.headline: Heat finish Lakers with 12-0 game-ending run
article.story:
LOS ANGELES (AP) -- The struggling Miami Heat finally reached 100. In doing so, they became the fourth last-place team to beat the Los Angeles Lakers in the past month. Alonzo Mourning had a season-high 28 points and 11 rebounds, and Jimmy Jackson scored eight of his 19 points in the fourth quarter Wednesday night as the Heat rallied to beat the Lakers 102-96. The Heat (10-26), who won for the fifth time in eight games, blew a 24-point lead before outscoring the Lakers 12-0 to finish the game. "To come from behind and win on the road is a great thing, especially against a team like this," said Miami's Eddie Jones, who played his first 4½ NBA seasons with the Lakers. "It's nice to get a win, we're struggling." The Heat went an NBA-record 35 straight games without scoring 100 points, and it appeared they might not make it again when they fell behind 92-86 on Lindsey Hunter's 3-point shot with 4:28 remaining. However, Mourning's dunk with 4:04 left, ending a Miami scoring drought of over 5½ minutes, got the Heat going. A jumper by Kobe Bryant with 3:03 to play put the Lakers ahead 96-90, but the Lakers wouldn't score again. Two free throws by Jackson with 1:23 left snapped a 96-all tie, and two foul shots by Rod Strickland and another pair by Jackson completed the scoring. "We're happy about the win, but we shouldn't be happy about the way we let the lead slip away," Jackson said. "We hit some baskets, Alonzo hit a big basket, so did Eddie, and we made our free throws." Strickland added 14 points and Eddie House and Eddie Jones scored 10 each for the Heat. Bryant led Los Angeles with 29 points, but made only 12-of-30 shots. Derek Fisher added 17 points and Samaki Walker had 14 points and 13 rebounds for the Lakers, who have lost to Memphis, Golden State, Chicago and Miami when each was in last place in their respective divisions. "This was the best worst team in the league," Walker said of the Heat. "You look at the guys they have on that team, you know they're talented." The Lakers, 27-9 and one game behind Sacramento in the Pacific Division, again played without Shaquille O'Neal, who sat out the second of a three-game suspension for fighting with Chicago's Brad Miller last Saturday night, and the Heat took advantage of his absence. Bryant scored 56 points in the first one despite sitting out the fourth quarter as the Lakers beat Memphis 120-81 on Monday night. This game didn't resemble that one in any way, and Bryant wasn't nearly as effective. "He was inspirational," Lakers coach Phil Jackson said. "(But) I think he'd like to have the last three minutes over again at the end of the game." The Lakers never led until a 9-0 run capped by Hunter's 3-pointer gave them a six-point lead. Shortly thereafter, the Heat turned things around. "I was pleased with how we just persevered," Mourning said. "We got a little complacent, complacency got us in trouble, we have a tendency to do that." Asked about the last three minutes, Mourning said, "We executed, made our shots and we rebounded the basketball." Bryant smiled when he was told the Heat had scored 100 points for the first time. "Hats off to them," he said. "It's bound to happen over an 82-game season." The Lakers, who trailed 53-29 with 5½ minutes left in the second quarter, tied the game 76-all on a 3-pointer by Rick Fox with 50 seconds to play in the third period. Miami led 80-78 entering the fourth quarter. Mourning scored 13 points and Miami made 17 of 24 shots in taking a 39-22 lead after the opening period. When Strickland went unchecked while driving for a layup, it capped a 30-12 run and gave the Heat their 24-point lead -- largest deficit the Lakers have faced this season. That seemed to start the Lakers, who outscored the Heat 19-7 to finish the second quarter, cutting Miami's lead to 60-48. Game notes
Averaging an NBA-low 83.7 points per game, Miami scored 28 in first half at Phoenix and 35 in the first half at Golden State in the first two games of its current four-game road trip. ... The Heat's 39 first-period points were the most they've scored and the most the Lakers have allowed in a quarter this season, and Miami's 60 first-half points were also a season-high. ... The Heat scored over 100 points 20 times last season. ...Miami, which set a league record by allowing only eight teams to reach 100 points last season, has held 31 of its 36 opponents under 100 this season. ... Lakers broadcaster Chick Hearn, who underwent open-heart surgery Dec. 19 and plans to return to work next month, is scheduled to hold a news conference Friday -- his first since the operation. Hearn had broadcast 3,338 straight Lakers games before the surgery.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
